titleStmt.title: question-answer session on issues of steelmaking
titleStmt.funder: The creation of VOICE 1.0 and 2.0 was funded by FWF, the Austrian Science Fund (Project No. L116 and L448). The creation of VOICE 3.0 Online and VOICE 3.0 XML was supported by funding from CLARIAH-AT and by staff members of the Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage at the Austrian Academy of Sciences and the English Department at the University of Vienna.

publicationStmt.distributor: Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage

availability.p: The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (VOICE) was created by Barbara Seidlhofer (founding director) and Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Marie-Luise Pitzl (project researchers) from 2005 to 2011. VOICE POS XML 2.0 was the first part-of-speech tagged version of VOICE and was based on the same data source as VOICE 2.0 XML (released 2013). VOICE 2.0 XML and VOICE POS XML 2.0 included minor revisions with regard to previous versions. VOICE 3.0 XML is a new, merged version of VOICE 2.0 XML and VOICE POS XML 2.0 and is available for download in ARCHE (A Resource Center for the HumanitiEs) under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) License 23 selected audio files are available as audio streams in the VOICE Online interface .

licence.p: You are free to: Share — copy and redistribute the material in any medium or format. Adapt — remix, transform, and build upon the material for any purpose, even commercially.

bibl.title: VOICE
The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English

availability.p: The recommended citation for VOICE 3.0 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2021. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (VOICE 3.0 XML). Founding director: Barbara Seidlhofer; Principal investigators VOICE 3.0: Marie-Luise Pitzl, Daniel Schopper; Researchers: Angelika Breiteneder, Hans-Christian Breuer, Nora Dorn, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Ruth Osimk-Teasdale, Hannes Pirker, Marie-Luise Pitzl, Michael Radeka, Stefanie Riegler, Barbara Seidlhofer, Omar Siam, Daniel Stoxreiter.

availability.p: The short citation for VOICE 3.0 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2021. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English ( VOICE 3.0 XML ).

availability.p: For further information about availability and copyright permissions, please see the README file included in the download package. For further enquiries please contact the VOICE Project at voice@univie.ac.at.

notesStmt.note: This question-answer session takes place after several presentations on steelmaking at a conference on this topic. S2 has just finished his presentation on a melt shop. S1, S2 and S4 are on the podium, S3 and S5 in the audience, asking questions.

equipment.p: Portable minidisc recorder with electret condenser stereo microphone

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark a stretch of speech commonly preceded and followed by a pause or by a change of speaker. A u is, however, not required to be bounded by a pause or a change of speaker, nor does it represent a turn in a conversation analytic sense. At a minimum, a u is some phonetic production or noise made by a given speaker or a group of speakers.
Used to mark contextual information relevant to the understanding of the interaction or the interaction as such. The voice:desc attribute provides a short prose description of the contextual event.

Used to mark text supplied by the transcriber because the original is unintelligible or needed to be anonymized. The reason attribute is used to mark:
unintelligible
unintelligible speech
anonymization
anonymized speech

Used to mark lengthening of sounds and intonation (fall, rise). The following type attributes are used to mark:
lengthening
lengthened sounds
intonation
a significant change in intonation, marked with the following function attribute for:
fall
falling intonation
rise
rising intonation
Intonation may or may not coincide with syntactic boundaries.
Used to mark a pause either between or within utterances. Used without dur attribute to indicate a brief pause up to half a second.

Used with different type attributes to mark:
type overlap
overlaps
type onomatopoeia
onomatopoeic sounds
type ipa
transcriptions in the international phonetic alphabet

Used to mark the point at which some paralinguistic feature changes. The following attribute values are used to mark:
voice
voice quality
imitating
laugh
neutral
phone
reading
reading_aloud
sigh
singing
whisp
yawning
tempo
speed of utterance
a
accelerando
l
lento
neutral
neutral
loud
loudness
f
neutral
p
Used to mark speech which is stressed or emphasized in a way that goes beyond regular nuclear stress.

Used to mark other-continuation, i.e. whenever a speaker continues another speaker's u without a pause. Other-continuation is to be interpreted temporally and does not relate to form or content of the speakers' utterances.
Used to mark speech which cannot be transcribed with certainty, because it is difficult to hear or understand for the transcriber.

Used to mark lexical forms (tokens), but also word fragments, pauses, onomatopoeic noises, spelling, laughter and breathing. w is used with ana and lemma attributes to mark its part-of-speech and lemma. The ana attribute may contain more than one reference if different interpretations are possible.

Used to mark laughter and other speaker noises and non-verbal feedback.
speaker_noise
coughing
nods
shakes head
smacks lips
sniffs
swallows
whistles
wordlike
laughing

namespace.name: http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark a pronunciation variation or coinage as described in the VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1].the VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1]. An existing word corresponding to the PVC may be provided within a commentcomment attribute within the voice:pvcvoice:pvc element. Additional phonetic transcription may be provided within a voice:ipavoice:ipa attribute within the voice:pvcvoice:pvc element.
Used to mark the beginning of a new audio track used in transcription (usually three minutes in length) and thus refers to the audio recording of the transcribed speech event.
